newsitem.title: pakistan: Pakistan devalues rupee in bid to rescue economy.
newsitem.headline: Pakistan devalues rupee in bid to rescue economy.

text.p: The State (central) Bank of Pakistan (SBP) devalued the rupee 7.86 percent against the dollar on Tuesday in what was seen as part of an IMF-approved economic rescue package.
The SBP lowered the value of the rupee to 40.1200/40.3206 to the dollar from 36.9700/37.1549 fixed on September 10, when a small downward adjustment took place.

There was no immediate official explanation for the sweeping devaluation. SBP governor Muhammad Yaqub was due to hold a news conference in Karachi at 1030 GMT (1530 local) and an SBP spokesman said he would outline the economic reform package.
The government has agreed with the International Monetary Fund on a series of stabilisation measures to cut Pakistan's budget deficit and bridge its yawning current account deficit.
The package, not yet announced, is expected to include harsh spending cuts and imposition of an agricultural income tax.
An IMF mission is due to arrive in Pakistan on Thursday for a review of the economy that must be completed before the fund can release more money from a stalled $600 million standby loan.
Pakistan's foreign reserves, excluding gold, stood at $1.13 billion in September, compared with $1.52 billion a year earlier, but had sunk to $831 million by October 3, SBP figures show.
The devaluation, which had been expected despite repeated SBP denials that any major adjustment was imminent, drew immediate criticism from bankers and analysts.

"This is not a concerted economic policy. Actually there is no economic policy," said a Lahore-based foreign banker, who asked not be named. "The devaluation will have no long- or short-term benefit because it will not spur any export growth."
He said devaluation was useful only in countries which have unutilised industrial capacity, which was not Pakistan's case.
A foreign banker in Karachi said the action was in line with government attempts to keep Pakistani exports competitive.
"Inflation running close to 10 percent and a high trade deficit, plus a strong dollar in the international markets must be the reasons behind the massive devaluation," he said.
The banker, who asked not to be named, said the rupee had lost 17.14 percent of its dollar value since January 1 and 14.3 percent since the beginning of fiscal 1996/97 (July-June).
"It's a disaster. The benefits are hard to see," said an Islamabad-based stocks analyst, adding that Pakistani exports and imports had not responded much to past devaluations.
"It won't affect exports, relieve the debt burden or add to reserves, but will push up fuel prices and power tariffs."
The analyst said stock prices were likely to fall because the devaluation would raise industrial costs, though the scrips of energy, fertiliser and fuel marketing companies might rise.
Karachi dealers said the sharp devaluation would send a shock wave to investors, prompting them to stay out for now.
The Karachi 100-share index fell 4.34 points, or 0.32 percent, to end at 1,363.26 on Monday.
